pageData.text: Plant roots need several things in order to grow, including appropriate temperature and sufficient air and water. In the Soil Water and Temperature lab, you will measure <button class='glossary-text'>soil moisture</button>, water flow rate, and soil temperature and examine connections between these properties and other physical properties of soil.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 15 minutes
Activity 1: Soil Water - 60 minutes plus up to 24 hours wait time for collected soil
Activity 2: Soil Moisture - 30 minutes plus 24 hours of wait time
Activity 3: Soil Temperature - 30 minutes
Activity 4: Computer Graphing of Soil Drainage - 20 minutes

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Piece of cardboard about the same width and length as the top of your 100 mL graduated cylinder (optional)
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos
Access to Microsoft Excel<sup>®</sup> or other computer program capable of graphing data sets

pageData.text: The albedo of the earth, or the fraction of the radiation from the sun that is reflected instead of absorbed, is an important factor driving the warming of the planet and global climate change. The overall albedo of the earth is decreasing, meaning that more heat is absorbed by its surface, allowing for more to be trapped by greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Much of this decrease is caused by melting snow and ice cover in the arctic, Antarctic, and from mountain glaciers; but other factors, like land use, also play a role.

Soil can help determine the albedo of the earth, and changes in its color, make-up, and whether it is exposed or covered can affect soil’s ability to buffer temperature changes. This has led scientists to wonder, can changing the types and timing of plants grown on crop land make a difference in the earth’s albedo and resulting temperatures? Some preliminary research says yes<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Scientists determined that crops like winter-sown barely had almost twice the albedo of bare soil, and that summer oats can decrease the amount of radiation absorbed in a localized area. While more research still needs to be done, the scientists are hopeful that modifying when and where certain crops are planted can help to increase albedo, decrease local temperatures, and decrease greenhouse gas emissions.

1Sieber, P., Böhme, S., Ericsson, N., & Hansson, P.-A. (2022). Albedo on cropland: Field-scale effects of current agricultural practices in Northern Europe. Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 321, 108978.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.agrformet.2022.108978

pageData.desc: A crop field with new seedlings emerging from the soil.
pageData.altText: A crop field with new seedlings emerging from the soil.

pageData.subTitle: Importance of Soil Water and Temperature on Plant Growth
pageData.text: Water availability is critical to all life on Earth. Immobile life forms, like plants, rely on the soil characteristics for access to water. Both the rate at which water flows through soil and the amount of water retained by soil are very important for access and overall plant growth. In either extreme of flow or retention, plants will not grow well. Characteristics like soil particle size, the physical properties of water, and their interaction are what influence the conditions that affect water availability for plants.

Plants live in a diverse number of environmental conditions that impact growth, and temperature is one that has the biggest impact on growth rate. If temperatures are too low, growth is slow; if temperatures are too high, important processes—such as photosynthesis—do not function. The effect of soil temperature on plant growth is twofold: it directly affects plant growth rate and germination, and indirectly affects plant growth by affecting nutrient solubility and the activity of microbes that support plant growth. For some plants, such as the lodgepole pine, germination can even be triggered by the extreme heat of fire (see Figure 1). Temperature also impacts nutrient availability. Generally, as temperature increases, chemical weathering of minerals accelerates, and nutrients in these minerals then dissolve into the soil solution faster as the soil warms.

Microbes also facilitate this weathering process, and they metabolize faster at warmer temperatures. The upper limit to this is above 35–40 °C, where plant and microbial growth slow as high temperatures inhibit enzyme activity and may evaporate water too quickly, leaving the soil too dry for plant growth.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Ashy gloved hands hold the serotinous cone of a lodgepole pine, opened by the flames of the Maple Fire.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Ashy gloved hands hold the serotinous cone of a lodgepole pine, opened by the flames of the Maple Fire.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Moisture
pageData.text: refers to the amount of water in soil; it can be measured by mass or volume. is the mass of the water in soil; it is measured by collecting moist soil, weighing it, drying it and then weighing it again. The percent gravimetric moisture is calculated using the following formula:

pageData.desc: Equation 1: theta sub m equals begin fraction mass of water over mass of dry soil end fraction equals begin fraction wet soil mass minus dry soil mass over dry soil mass
pageData.altText: Equation 1: theta sub m equals begin fraction mass of water over mass of dry soil end fraction equals begin fraction wet soil mass minus dry soil mass over dry soil mass

pageData.text: Note that the denominator is the dry weight of the soil. Therefore, gravimetric soil moisture is not a typical percent, but rather a water-to soil weight ratio, with units in g/g or kg/kg. Any weight unit is appropriate, so long as the same unit is used in the numerator and denominator.

In this lab, you will be air-drying soil. In research labs, soil is dried in the oven. Most oven-drying procedures call for drying at 105° C for 16–24 hours. This high temperature is important to evaporate all water in the pores of the soil. It is possible, however, that trace amounts of water vapor may remain adsorbed to the soil or may absorb from the atmosphere once the soil is removed from the oven.
In practical applications, water content is often measured in volume, or depth, as we measure water in a rain gage. can be calculated as follows:

pageData.desc: Equation 2: theta sub v equal begin fraction volume of water over volume of soil end fraction equals begin fraction V sub w over V sub s end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 2: theta sub v equal begin fraction volume of water over volume of soil end fraction equals begin fraction V sub w over V sub s end fraction

pageData.text: Unlike gravimetric soil moisture, volumetric soil moisture is a typical fraction, since the denominator is the total soil volume. Units are typically in cm<sup>3</sup> per cm<sup>3</sup>, but as with gravimetric moisture, any unit of volume can be used so long as it is the same in the numerator and denominator. Note that since the density of water is 1 g/cm<sup>3</sup> at room temperature, the volume of water in cm<sup>3</sup> is effectively equal to its mass in grams. Thus, with a known volume of soil, the volume of water can be inferred after drying the soil and weighing it, as a displacement of 1 cm<sup>3</sup> of water is equal to 1 g of mass.

Volumetric moisture can be converted to a depth, or volume. For example, if you know the volumetric of a pot of soil, to calculate how many cm3 (same as mL) of water are in the pot, the previous formula can be used to solve for volume of water as follows:

pageData.desc: Equation 3: volume of water equals theta sub V times volume of soil or V sub w equals theta sub V times V sub s
pageData.altText: Equation 3: volume of water equals theta sub V times volume of soil or V sub w equals theta sub V times V sub s

pageData.text: A similar formula can be used for depth. Rainfall is typically reported as a depth, and irrigation recommendations are made in depth units. Depth of water can be calculated as follows:

pageData.desc: Equation 4: depth of water equals theta sub V times depth of soil or D sub w equals theta sub V times D sub s
pageData.altText: Equation 4: depth of water equals theta sub V times depth of soil or D sub w equals theta sub V times D sub s

pageData.text: Where Dw = depth of water, and Ds = depth of soil. Using depth is very useful when the depth of a soil is known, but not its volume, or to determine the depth of water to apply for irrigation. For example, in topsoil 15 cm deep, to bring the soil moisture up to θv = 0.33 cm3/cm3 (or 33%), the following calculation is used:
D w = θv * D s = 0.33*15 cm = 5 cm

Given this result, 5 cm of water depth would need to be added to the soil surface to achieve a <button class='glossary-text'>volumetric soil moisture</button> of 0.33 cm<sup>3</sup>/cm<sup>3</sup> from the surface down to 15 cm of depth.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Water Potential
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Water potential (Ψ)</button> is defined as the potential energy of the water. It is quantified as the amount of energy needed to move water from a pool of pure water to a known location in soil. Water potential is a type of pressure, and in soils it is measured in units of kilopascals (kPa).

Water always flows from high to low potential energy. Specifically, it flows from high to low . In soil, total water potential is the sum of four types of potential energy:
  1. : the potential due to gravity. Gravitational potential increases with increasing elevation, and hence causes water to flow from high elevations to low elevations.
  2. : the potential due to . Capillarity is the phenomenon whereby water is drawn into narrow spaces in soil. Capillarity occurs due to: a) adhesion, the attraction of water molecules to polar surfaces of soil particles and b) cohesion of water molecules attracted to each other. Matric potential is lower in smaller pores. Therefore, matric potential causes water to flow from large to small pores in soil.
  3. : the potential due to dissolved solutes. The greater the concentration of solutes such as salts and sugars, the lower the osmotic potential. This causes water to flow from areas of low to high solute concentrations in soil.
  4. : the potential due to overlying layers of water pressing down on the point of interest. Hydrostatic potential is usually negligible, but becomes significantly positive in flooded soils. This type of potential, opposite from gravitational potential, increases with increasing depth in a flooded soil.

Water tends to flow into soil instead of out of soil. This is because the matric potential of soil water is usually negative. Like a sponge or paper towel, soil <button class='glossary-text'>micropores</button> “suck” up water due to capillary action. Most of this suction (negative pressure) is due to the negative matric potential of soil pores. Water is attracted to polar soil minerals such as quartz and feldspar because water itself is polar, having a partial negative charge on its O atom, and a partial positive charge on its H atoms. This attraction causes adhesion, which draws water closer to the minerals, especially into small pores where the water can come into contact with more mineral surfaces.

Generally, the drier the soil, the more negative pressure it can exert, and the more negative (lower) its matric potential becomes. Conversely, the wetter the soil, the more positive (higher) its matric potential becomes. There are three specific soil matric potentials that are especially relevant to plants and microbes: saturation, , and (Table 1). In , all pores are completely filled with water, and a positive matric potential exists. A soil is at field capacity after it has been saturated and any unbound water has drained. As soil dries, water films get thinner and thinner, and the matric potential continues to lower (more and more negative). At the permanent wilting point, water still exists in the soil, but the matric potential is so low it is nearly inaccessible to the plant.

Both soil texture and organic matter content affect the amount of water held at <button class='glossary-text'>field capacity</button>. As particle size decreases, water held at field capacity generally increases. Fine-textured (i.e., clayey) soils therefore hold more water at field capacity than coarse-textured (i.e., sandy) soils. This occurs because clay particles create <button class='glossary-text'>micropores</button> between them, as soils with more clay have more micropores that hold onto more water. However, very clayey soils also hold onto more water at the <button class='glossary-text'>permanent wilting point</button>; as they can hold onto a significant amount of water too tightly for plants to access it. Therefore, silt loam soils with medium-sized particles and medium-sized pores can retain the greatest amount of plant-available water.

Organic matter retains more water than sand at field capacity, but less water than clay at the permanent wilting point. This occurs because pores in organic matter are at a size to hold onto water after rain, but not so small that plants can’t remove water from them. As a result, plant-available water increases dramatically with increasing organic matter content. Adding compost and other practices that increase soil organic matter can therefore increase plant growth and reduce irrigation needs.

tableData.hoverText: An illustration of a soil with its pore spaces filled with water and excess water dripping from the soil into a pan.
An illustration of a soil with its pore spaces filled with water. No excess water drips from the soil.
An illustration of a soil with empty pore spaces.

tableData.text: Mostly empty, water coats soil particles in a very thin film
Too much water, not enough air for plants
Sufficient air and water for plant growth
Remaining water not available to plants

pageData.subTitle: Flow of Water Through Soil
pageData.text: Like water flowing through a pipe, as soil pore size increases, so does water flow speed. Consequently, water flows through (>80 μm in diameter) faster than micropores (<80 μm in diameter). Generally, average soil pore size increases with increasing particle size. Hence, water flows fastest between sand particles, followed by silt, and finally clay (Figure 2). In fact, water flows so slowly through clay that fine clays such as bentonite are used to line waste pits and prevent contaminated water from percolating down into the groundwater table.

pageData.disc: Figure 2: Comparison of water flowing through larger particles (sand) versus smaller particles (silt)
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Comparison of water flowing through larger particles (sand) versus smaller particles (silt)

pageData.text: The rate of water flow also depends on <button class='glossary-text'>matric potential</button>. This is because water can only flow through water-filled pores. As soil pores fill with water, the water can flow through a better-connected network of pores and take a more direct path through the soil (Figure 3). As the soil drains, the water must take a more winding path through the soil, adhering to individual particles through fewer and less-connected water-filled pores, slowing down the water flow rate. Thus, water flow rate increases as moisture and matric potential increase.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: As soil pores fill with water, the water can flow through a better-connected network of pores and take a more direct path through the soil.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: As soil pores fill with water, the water can flow through a better-connected network of pores and take a more direct path through the soil.

pageData.question: As soil matric potential increases, how does the water flow rate change?

options.text: water flows faster
water flows lower
water flow rate increases then decreases
water flow rate decreases then increases
water flow rate remains the same

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water can only flow through water-filled pores. As soil pores fill with water, the water can flow through a better-connected network of pores and take a more direct path through the soil. Thus, water flow rate increases as moisture and matric potential increase.

pageData.question: Through which type of soil would you expect water to flow the slowest?

options.text: clay
sand
silt
organic
loam

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As particle size decreases, water must weave around the soil particles and travel through smaller pores. Due to capillary action and friction, water flowing through smaller pores travels much more slowly than through large pores. In other words, the closer a water molecule is to a more hydrophilic surface, the more it is attracted to that surface, and the slower it will move. In smaller pores, a greater proportion of the water molecules are closer to the surface and will therefore move slower.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Like water flowing through a pipe, as soil pore size increases, so does water flow speed. Consequently, water flows through macropores (>80 μm in diameter) faster than micropores (<80 μm in diameter). Generally, average soil pore size increases with increasing particle size. Hence, water flows fastest between sand particles, followed by silt, and finally clay. The rate of water flow also depends on matric potential. This is because water can only flow through water-filled pores. As soil pores fill with water, the water can flow through a better-connected network of pores and take a more direct path through the soil (Figure 3). As the soil drains, the water must take a more winding path through the soil, adhering to individual particles through fewer and less-connected water-filled pores, slowing down the water flow rate. Thus, water flow rate increases as moisture and matric potential increase.

Hence, water flows fastest between sand particles, followed by silt, and finally clay. The rate of water flow also depends on matric potential. This is because water can only flow through water-filled pores. As soil pores fill with water, the water can flow through a better-connected network of pores and take a more direct path through the soil (Figure 3). As the soil drains, the water must take a more winding path through the soil, adhering to individual particles through fewer and less-connected water-filled pores, slowing down the water flow rate. Thus, water flow rate increases as moisture and matric potential increase.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Temperature
pageData.text: Temperature is the average kinetic energy of a substance, measured in degrees Fahrenheit, Celsius, or Kelvin. Understanding soil temperature is necessary in order to manage it for optimal crop growth, and to understand ecological patterns observed across a landscape. Four key factors affect the temperature of soil: solar radiation absorbed by soil, soil <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>soil moisture</button>, and the depth in soil at which temperature is measured.

Solar radiation is energy from the sun. If this energy reaches the soil, it will increase the temperature. Many factors affect how much radiation reaches the soil, including: latitude, climate, albedo, slope angle, and aspect. Incoming solar radiation increases with decreasing latitude, and so land closer to the equator receives more hours of sunlight and more direct sunlight compared with land closer to the poles. Humid regions receive less solar radiation than dry regions because water vapor absorbs solar radiation, and clouds reflect it. Both absorption and reflection of radiation by the atmosphere reduces the amount reaching the soil. Light-colored and snow-covered soils have a much higher albedo compared with darker, exposed soils. Thus, darker soils, when not covered by snow, absorb more radiation, and heat up faster than light colored or snow-covered soils. The location of soil on a slope also affects the amount of solar radiation it absorbs.

In the Northern Hemisphere, south-facing slopes receive more direct sunlight, and more hours of sunlight, than north-facing slopes. Therefore, soils on south-facing slopes in the Northern Hemisphere have higher temperatures on average than those on north-facing slopes. The opposite occurs in the Southern Hemisphere. Finally, plants, landforms, and man-made structures that shade the soil reduce the amount of solar radiation reaching the soil. Deliberately shading soil can be advantageous in hot, dry environments such as deserts.

Once solar radiation does reach the soil, the specific heat and moisture of the soil affect how much the temperature of the soil actually increases. Specific heat is the amount of energy required to increase the temperature of a material by 1° C per unit mass (measured in cal/g or J/g). The higher the specific heat of a material, the more energy it takes to warm it up. The specific heat of water (1 cal/g) is much greater than that of soil minerals (~0.2 cal/g on average). Therefore, the specific heat of soil increases with increasing gravimetric moisture. Thus, wetter soils warm more slowly than drier soils. This effect is exacerbated by high of water. Heat of vaporization is the amount of energy needed to turn a material into a gas. Water’s high specific heat of vaporization (540 cal/g) causes water to cool as it evaporates, cooling the soil.

Lastly, soil temperature varies with depth in the soil. The top layers of soil insulate lower layers from both heat gain and heat loss. During a hot day, soil temperature therefore generally decreases with increasing depth (see Figure 4) for hypothetical soil temperature trends over time in a warm, dry climate). During a cold night, however, temperature generally increases with increasing depth, as the deeper soil layers are more protected from the cold evening air. Deeper layers of soil also tend to take longer to heat up and cool down, as the heat must travel through more layers to enter or exit the soil. This delay in peak and trough temperatures is called lag time. Adding mulch or gravel to soil effectively adds an extra layer of “blanket”, insulating the soil further, and increasing the lag time.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Hypothetical soil temperature trends over time in a warm, dry climate; the x-axis shows time of day, and the y-axis shows soil temperature readings in Fahrenheit
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Hypothetical soil temperature trends over time in a warm, dry climate; the x-axis shows time of day, and the y-axis shows soil temperature readings in Fahrenheit

pageData.text: In this lab, you will measure characteristics of soils that are important for water retention, and thus the water available for plants, including water flow rate through a soil and water retention at <button class='glossary-text'>field capacity</button> by measuring <button class='glossary-text'>gravimetric</button> <button class='glossary-text'>soil moisture</button>. Finally, you will assess the impact of solar radiation on soil temperature at six local environments of your choosing.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about soil temperature is true?

options.text: Wet soil warms slower than dry soil.
Darker soils have a higher albedo and heat up slower than light-colored soils.
Soil on a slope will always warm faster than soil on flat terrain.
Soils are warmed by heat from the earth’s core.
Soil temperature is uniform regardless of depth.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water has a high specific heat relative to many substances, including soil. Thus, wetter soils warm more slowly than drier soils. Water also has a high heat of vaporization, so it cools as it evaporates, thus cooling surrounding soil.

pageData.question: Mindy is measuring soil temperature at a field site. The air temperature is -5° C (23° F). Which of the following statements best describes the expected temperature of the soil as Mindy digs deeper into it?

options.text: It increases.
It decreases.
It increases through the B horizon, then decreases.
It decreases through the B horizon, then increases.
It is uniform regardless of depth.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As soil depth increases, the soil temperature becomes closer to the average temperature. This means that, on a cold day, temperature will likely increase with increasing depth.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Four key factors affect the temperature of soil: solar radiation absorbed by soil, soil specific heat, soil moisture, and the depth in soil at which temperature is measured. Solar radiation is energy from the sun. If this energy reaches the soil, it will increase the temperature. Incoming solar radiation increases with decreasing latitude, and so land closer to the equator receives more hours of sunlight and more direct sunlight compared with land closer to the poles. Light-colored and snow-covered soils have a much higher albedo compared with darker, exposed soils. Thus, darker soils, when not covered by snow, absorb more radiation, and heat up faster than light colored or snow-covered soils. The location of soil on a slope also affects the amount of solar radiation it absorbs. A slope facing the direction opposite of the hemisphere in which it is located (I.e., a south-facing slope in the Nothern Hemisphere) will receive more direct and a longer duration of sunlight, causing soil on these slopes to be warmer. Once solar radiation does reach the soil, the specific heat and moisture of the soil affect how much the temperature of the soil increases. The higher the specific heat of a material, the more energy it takes to warm it up.  Water has a greater specific heat than that of soil minerals, therefore wetter soils warm more slowly than drier soils. This effect is exacerbated by high heat of vaporization of water, which causes water to cool as it evaporates, cooling the soil. Lastly, soil temperature varies with depth in the soil. The top layers of soil insulate lower layers from both heat gain and heat loss. Deeper layers of soil also tend to take longer to heat up and cool down, as the heat must travel through more layers to enter or exit the soil. This delay in peak and trough temperatures is called lag time.

A slope facing the direction opposite of the hemisphere in which it is located (I.e., a south-facing slope in the Nothern Hemisphere) will receive more direct and a longer duration of sunlight, causing soil on these slopes to be warmer. Once solar radiation does reach the soil, the specific heat and moisture of the soil affect how much the temperature of the soil increases. The higher the specific heat of a material, the more energy it takes to warm it up.  Water has a greater specific heat than that of soil minerals, therefore wetter soils warm more slowly than drier soils. This effect is exacerbated by high heat of vaporization of water, which causes water to cool as it evaporates, cooling the soil. Lastly, soil temperature varies with depth in the soil. The top layers of soil insulate lower layers from both heat gain and heat loss. Deeper layers of soil also tend to take longer to heat up and cool down, as the heat must travel through more layers to enter or exit the soil. This delay in peak and trough temperatures is called lag time.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will label the cups, collect your soil sample and mix sample Z and sand.  In activity 1, you will measure the soil volume, set up the filter apparatus and add the soil to it. Then, you will pour water through the soil in the filter. Next, you will record the time to the first drop of water passing through the filter and then continue recording the time and volume of water passing through the filter. Then, you will cover the cup and filter with a plastic bag and wait 24 hours. Next, you will record the final filtered water volume. Repeat this procedure for the other sample. In activity 2, you will remove the plastic bag from the filter and record the mass of the filter and soil. Then, you will allow the soil to dry on newspaper until it feels dry. Next, you will record the mass of the dry soil and calculate the soil moisture. You will then proceed to activity 3.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will label the cups, collect your soil sample and mix sample Z and sand.  In activity 1, you will measure the soil volume, set up the filter apparatus and add the soil to it. Then, you will pour water through the soil in the filter. Next, you will record the time to the first drop of water passing through the filter and then continue recording the time and volume of water passing through the filter. Then, you will cover the cup and filter with a plastic bag and wait 24 hours. Next, you will record the final filtered water volume. Repeat this procedure for the other sample. In activity 2, you will remove the plastic bag from the filter and record the mass of the filter and soil. Then, you will allow the soil to dry on newspaper until it feels dry. Next, you will record the mass of the dry soil and calculate the soil moisture. You will then proceed to activity 3.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will decide on your test sites and mark your thermometer. Then, you will draw a map of the soil locations and photograph your test sites. Next, you will insert your thermometer to the given depth, wait 2 minutes, then remove the thermometer and record the temperature. You will do this at all your test sites at soil depths of 1, 2, 4, and 6 centimeters. In Activity 4, you will create a spreadsheet workbook table and enter water drainage data into it. Then you will create a graph from the data. This process is repeated for each data set from Activity 2.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will decide on your test sites and mark your thermometer. Then, you will draw a map of the soil locations and photograph your test sites. Next, you will insert your thermometer to the given depth, wait 2 minutes, then remove the thermometer and record the temperature. You will do this at all your test sites at soil depths of 1, 2, 4, and 6 centimeters. In Activity 4, you will create a spreadsheet workbook table and enter water drainage data into it. Then you will create a graph from the data. This process is repeated for each data set from Activity 2.

Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron for the duration of this investigation.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity, Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: How do water flow rates affect plant growth?

options.text: If flow rates are too slow, the soil drains too slowly and roots cannot get enough oxygen.
If flow rates are too slow, the soil drains too slowly and roots cannot get enough water.
If flow rates are too fast, the soil drains too quickly and roots cannot get enough oxygen.
If flow rates are too fast, the soil drains too quickly and the roots get too much water.
Flow rates do not affect plant growth.

assestmentData.question: Total water potential is the sum of what types of potential energy?

options.text: gravitational + matric + osmotic + hydrostatic
gravitational + osmotic + hydrostatic
gravitational + matric + osmotic + capillarity
osmotic + capillarity + matric
osmotic + capillarity + matric + hydrostatic

assestmentData.question: Capillarity in soil occurs due to which of the following properties of water?

options.text: adhesion and cohesion
hydrogen bonding and high specific heat
polarity and high osmotic potential
high hydrostatic potential
surface tension and high heat of vaporization

assestmentData.question: How is the matric potential related to water flow?

options.text: A low matric potential results in slower water flow.
A low matric potential results in faster water flow.
A high matric potential results in slow water flow.
A high matric potential results in variable water flow.
There is no relationship between matric potential and water flow.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements best describes soil pores in soils that have reached the permanent wilting point?

options.text: The pores are mostly empty, with soil particles coated in a very thin film of water.
Only the micropores are filled with water.
All the pores are filled with water.
The pores are empty, with soil particles charged by negative ions.
Only the macropores are filled with water.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?

options.text: graphing software
a sand sample
a ruler
2 volunteers
distilled water

assestmentData.question: After a hot day, how does the soil temperature change with increasing depth?

options.text: It decreases.
It increases.
It increases then decreases.
It decreases then increases.
It stays the same temperature throughout the depth of the soil.

assestmentData.question: If a soil has a specific heat of 0.25 J/g, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: It takes 0.25 J of energy to increase the temperature of 1 g of soil by 1° C.
1 g of soil will increase by 25% for every 1 hour it is exposed to solar radiation.
It takes 0.25 J of energy to warm 1 g of soil to 25° C.
1 g of soil gives off 0.25 J of energy for every 1 hour that it cools.
1 g of soil contains 0.25 J of energy for plants to use.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activities.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work space.
Obtain the 2 plastic cups. Label the cups “Mix” and “Collected Soil”.

Using the 24-oz deli container from the equipment kit, collect approximately 1 cup of soil from about 0–8 cm (0–3 in) below the surface. This sample is the “Collected Soil” sample and will be used in all the activities. Before using the sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials and break up any large clumps.
Label the resealable bag, “Mix”.
Use the digital scale and weigh boat and measure 5 g of Sample Z. Pour it into the “Mix” bag.
Use the digital scale and weigh boat to measure 25 g of fine sand. Pour it into the “Mix” bag.
Thoroughly mix the sample, breaking up aggregates or clumps.

Note: Before using the collected soil sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials and break up any large clumps. You may need to spread the soil out flat to find most of the plant residues. If your soil has a substantial amount (>10% or so) of course fragments like gravel or plant debris, you can sieve it with a colander or a sieve.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: a metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained
pageData.altText: Figure 5: a metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained

pageData.text: If you are unsure if a public location is appropriate to collect a sample from, contact your local Park and Recreation, Fish and Wildlife, State Park, Bureau of Land Management, or National Forest Department.
In Activity 1, you will set up filter apparatuses with your collected and mixed soils. You will use the soil and filter apparatuses in Activity 2 and the data in Activity 4.
Obtain the 2 plastic cups. Label the cups “Mixed Soil” and “Collected Soil”. Use the 100 mL graduated cylinder to pour 100 mL of tap water into each of the cups.

Obtain a funnel and coffee filter. Open the coffee filter and place the filter in the funnel. Wet the filter slightly with water to get it to stick to the inside of the funnel. This is your “filter apparatus”.

Use the digital scale. Tare the scale with the empty plastic cup on it. Put the “filter apparatus” on the cup. Measure the weight of the “filter apparatus” (see Figure 6). Record the mass in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: How to Use a Digital Scale

pageData.text: Note: The empty cup is only used to stabilize the “filter apparatus” so that a more accurate measurement can be obtained.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: clear plastic cup with a metal funnel inside on top of a digital scale
pageData.altText: Figure 6: clear plastic cup with a metal funnel inside on top of a digital scale

pageData.text: Use the 100 mL graduated cylinder to measure ~30 mL of the “Collected Soil” sample. Record the exact volume in Data Table 1.
Carefully pour the measured soil into the filter.
Rinse out the graduated cylinder.
Place the “filter apparatus” on top of the 100 mL graduated cylinder (see Figure 7).

pageData.desc: Figure 7: clear plastic graduated cylinder with a metal funnel sitting inside
pageData.altText: Figure 7: clear plastic graduated cylinder with a metal funnel sitting inside

pageData.text: Cut off the bottom of another coffee filter and cut it half to make two equal pieces. Push one of the pieces down into the funnel and completely cover the soil. You will use the second piece for your second sample (see Figure 8).

pageData.desc: Figure 8: an aerial view of a funnel containing two pieces of a coffee filter that are sitting inside
pageData.altText: Figure 8: an aerial view of a funnel containing two pieces of a coffee filter that are sitting inside

pageData.text: Start the timer and slowly pour the cup of tap water labeled “Collected Soil” over the filter and soil. Do not pour too fast, or this will stir up the soil.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Pour ~20–50 mL every 10 seconds, maintaining at least an inch of water over the filter and soil. If the filter becomes full, do not add more water. Do not allow the water to go above the filter.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Record the amount of time it took for the first drop to emerge from the funnel. Record this value in Data Table 2. The first drop is likely to be less than 1 mL and too small to measure with a graduated cylinder; therefore, record as ~0.3 mL in Data Table 2.
As water begins to pass through the funnel, add more water to the filter and the soil.
Continue to monitor the flow of water into the graduated cylinder.
When 10–20 mL of filtered water has entered the graduated cylinder, record the volume and the amount of time that has elapsed in Data Table 2.
Continue to add the cup of water until it has all been added to the sample.
Continue to record the volume and time of the filtered water at 10–20 mL intervals. Record your data in Data Table 2.
Record the time when the soil appears to be completed wetted in Data Table 2.

Note: For soils that are draining less than 10 mL per 15 minutes, if recording the water volume every 10–20 mL would require you stay up all night or miss a class, you are not required to do this. Record the next reading when it is possible.
Stop collecting interval data after you have at least five data points.
Record the final volume of water that passed through the soil and the time that has elapsed in Data Table 2.
Cover the funnel with a plastic bag and attach with a rubber band around the funnel to secure the bag and to prevent evaporation.
Allow the soil to continue to drain for ~24 hr.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 2–22 for the “Mixed Soil” sample, and record those results in Data Table 3.
After 24 hours, record the filtered water volume for both samples in Data Table 2 and Data Table 3.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: If after 24 hours there is standing water on the soil sample, gently pour it off into the 100 mL graduated cylinder. Record the volume that was poured off in the corresponding data table.
The soil is now approximately at <button class='glossary-text'>field capacity</button> (<button class='glossary-text'>matric potential</button> = -33 kPa).
Save the soil and “filter apparatus” for use in Activity 2.

In Activity 2, you will use the soil and filter apparatuses from Activity 1 and record the mass of the soil before and after drying. You will then calculate <button class='glossary-text'>soil moisture</button>.
Remove the plastic bag and rubber band from the “filter apparatus”.
Use the digital scale. Tare the scale with the empty plastic cup on it. Put the “filter apparatus” with soil sample on the cup. Measure the “filter apparatus”. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
Note: The empty cup is only used to stabilize the “filter apparatus” with the soil sample so that a more accurate measurement can be obtained.
Place the newspaper on a paper towel. Carefully transfer the soil sample to the newspaper and spread it out.
Allow the soil to dry approximately 24 hours. Check to see if the soil feels dry before continuing.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: If humidity is high, the soil may take longer to dry. A gentle fan can be used to speed up drying. If using a fan, check on the soil regularly (every 4–8 hrs), as the fan can blow fine particles around, causing a dust inhalation hazard and a loss of the soil.
After your soil is dry, weigh the dry soil and record the results in Data Table 1.
Perform the necessary calculations in Data Table 1 to determine the .
θm = wetmass - drymass/drymass
Repeat steps 1-6 for the second “filter apparatus”.

In Activity 3, you will select an environmental factor and map out test sites to test the effect of this factor on soil temperature. You will then measure the soil temperature of your test sites at different depths.

Select an area to test based on the envi-ronmental conditions. A garden, lawn, or other area containing a variety of environmental conditions for comparisons is ideal. For example, common comparisons that exist in many locations include:
  1. Shaded vs. unshaded areas
  2. Soil cover: grass, mulch, gravel, etc. vs. uncovered
  3. Coarse vs. fine soil textures
  4. Plants vs. no plants
  5. Dense plants vs. sparse plants
You will need to sample from six different locations in the selected area that vary in environmental conditions.
Try to choose three locations for each of the comparisons that you have identified.

Obtain all materials that you need before starting the field trip. Make sure that you have a thermometer, gloves, goggles, apron, a permanent marker, a piece of paper, camera, and Data Table 4 and Data Table 5.
Use the ruler to measure 1, 2, 4, and 6 cm from the bottom tip of the thermometer. Use the permanent marker or a piece of tape to mark these locations on the thermometer.
Note: While you are in the field, the marks you made on the thermometer may scrape off. Make sure you have the ruler and marker with you in the field to redo the measurements, if needed.
Draw an approximate map of your chosen soil location in the Notes section, and number the locations 1–6 on your map.
Take pictures of each location and upload them into the Lab Notebook.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Record your observations and environmental conditions for each location in Data Table 4.

At the first chosen location, slowly and carefully insert the thermometer to 1 cm. Wait 2 minutes for the temperature to stabilize. After 2 minutes, carefully remove the thermometer from the soil and record the temperature in Data Table 5.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: Make sure the thermometer is pointing straight down into the soil. Take care not to push too hard, as to avoid accidentally breaking the thermometer. If you feel resistance, try another spot. Otherwise, you could accidentally puncture irrigation lines or break the thermometer.
Repeat Step 4 for the 2, 4, and 6-cm depths. If too much resistance is present in the soil and you cannot push down deep enough, choose shallower depths; for example, 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 cm.
Repeat Steps 4–5 for the other five chosen locations.
In Activity 4, you will use the data from Activity 1 to graph the water drainage of the two soil samples.

pages.title: Computer Graphing of Soil Drainage (12 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Computer Graphing of Soil Drainage (12 steps)

pageData.text: Open a new workbook. This will open a new sheet (see Figure 9).

typeBefore.text: Graphing by hand can be useful for observing trends in small data sets. However, as the quantity of the data grows, it can be useful to graph using a computer. This activity will give a general outline of how to graph on a computer.

Note: Microsoft Excel® was used to generate the figures for this activity. Your exact software may look different or have slightly different labeling than what you will see here. You may need to refer to the documentation of your exact program to determine how to perform a particular step.
In this activity, you will graph the data collected from Data Table 2 and Data Table 3 into your graphing software.

pageData.desc: Figure 9: a blank workbook in Microsoft Excel showing 7 rows and 3 columns labeled A–C
pageData.altText: Figure 9: a blank workbook in Microsoft Excel showing 7 rows and 3 columns labeled A–C

pageData.text: You will see a large sheet with lettered columns and numbered rows. These letters and numbers can be used to refer to a specific cell (the box where information can be typed). For example, the upper left cell is “A1”, representing column A, row 1.
Starting in cell A1, type, “Time (min)”. In cell B1, type “Mixed Soil Volume (mL)”.
Move to row 2. Type the corresponding numbers under the correct column.
Continue until your table looks like Data Table 2.

Select the data for “Time” through “Mixed Soil Volume”. You can do this by clicking on cell A1 and then dragging down and over to the last cell containing data. All of the data and titles should be selected for the “Mixed Soil” sample (see Figure 10 for an example a completed data table).

pageData.desc: Figure 10: Excel workbook showing 9 rows of data; the first column shows time data (in minutes) and the second column shows mixed soil volume data (in milliliters)
pageData.altText: Figure 10: Excel workbook showing 9 rows of data; the first column shows time data (in minutes) and the second column shows mixed soil volume data (in milliliters)

pageData.text: Note: The next several steps may vary greatly depending on the exact software you are using, but the goal is the same.
Find the menu labeled “Insert”.
Among the “Charts”, find “Line”, and click it.
A basic graph similar to Figure 11 should appear.

pageData.desc: Figure 11: Water drainage line graph showing time (in minutes) along the x-axis, and water volume drained from mixed soil (in millimeters) along the y-axis. The line has a positive slope
pageData.altText: Figure 11: Water drainage line graph showing time (in minutes) along the x-axis, and water volume drained from mixed soil (in millimeters) along the y-axis. The line has a positive slope

pageData.text: Edit the chart title. This can usually be accomplished by clicking (or double clicking) on the title and then typing.

You can then add a label to each axis. This step in particular is very different depending on your software. You will typically be looking for a menu option titled “Axis Title.” You will need to do this twice, once for each axis. Your graph should now look like Figure 11. Save an image of your graph and upload it to the Lab Notebook.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Repeat steps 2-11 for Data Table 3.

text: Wash the equipment with soap and water.
You will need to dry the sands and the soil samples and put them back into their bags once they are dry. You may need them for use in future investigations.

Label a piece of cardboard or a sheet of newspaper with the name of the soil. If using newspaper, place it on a paper towel. Spread out the soil on the cardboard or newspaper and allow it to dry. Once the soil sample is dry, put it back into the bag. You may need to use the sample again in future investigations.
Sanitize the work space, and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

text:
Compare the water flow (drainage) rates you observed for the mixed soil versus your collected soil.
  1. Which soil appeared to have the fastest drainage?

pageData.text: 1. What other soil property most likely explains this? Describe this property for each soil and explain how it may have led to the observed result.
1. Do the results match your hypothesis? Why or why not?

text: In theory, as particle size increases, should soil moisture at field capacity increase or decrease? Why?

From the volumetric water content of your collected soil at field capacity, calculate:
  1. How much water would there be total in a 1000 mL pot of soil at this moisture? Calculate your answer in mL.

pageData.text: 1. How much water would there be, in cm, to a 15 cm rooting depth? Calculate your answer in cm (the calculation is the same as in part a, despite the different units. Depth units are common in soil science because precipitation and irrigation are also measured as depths).

tableData.text: Estimated relative soil moisture (high, med, low)
Other observations (mulch, compost, tillage, north/south facing slope)

text: What was the effect of depth on soil temperature overall? Did the effect of depth on soil temperature agree with your hypothesis? Why or why not?

Compare the results you recorded in Data Table 4 with Data Table 5. How did the following affect soil temperature (if at all)? Were effects larger or smaller deeper in the soil?
  1. Shading

pageData.text: 1. Apparent soil moisture
1. Soil color (light vs. dark), if applicable
1. Other observations, if any (mulch, compost, tillage, burrowing animals, north/south facing slope, etc.)

text: Did the effects in the previous question agree or disagree with your hypothesis? Why? (If not, what might explain the difference?)

pageData.desc: Equation 1: theta sub v equal begin fraction volume of water over volume of soil end fraction equals begin fraction V sub w over V sub s end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 1: theta sub m equals begin fraction mass of water over mass of dry soil end fraction equals begin fraction wet soil mass minus dry soil mass over dry soil mass

pageData.desc: Equation 2: theta sub v equal begin fraction volume of water over volume of soil end fraction equals begin fraction V sub w over V sub s end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 2: theta sub v equal begin fraction volume of water over volume of soil end fraction equals begin fraction V sub w over V sub s end fraction

pageData.desc: Equation 3: volume of water equals theta sub v times begin paren volume of soil end paren
pageData.altText: Equation 3: volume of water equals theta sub V times volume of soil or V sub w equals theta sub V times V sub s

pageData.desc: Equation 4: depth of water equals theta sub v times begin paren depth of soil end paren or D sub w equals Theta sub v times D sub s
pageData.altText: Equation 4: depth of water equals theta sub V times depth of soil or D sub w equals theta sub V times D sub s

pageData.content: Figure 4. Average Summer Soil Temperature Fluctuations
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Hypothetical soil temperature trends over time in a warm, dry climate; the x-axis shows time of day, and the y-axis shows soil temperature readings in Fahrenheit

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will label the cups, collect your soil sample and mix sample Z and sand.  In activity 1, you will measure the soil volume, set up the filter apparatus and add the soil to it. Then, you will pour water through the soil in the filter. Next, you will record the time to the first drop of water passing through the filter and then continue recording the time and volume of water passing through the filter. Then, you will cover the cup and filter with a plastic bag and wait 24 hours. Next, you will record the final filtered water volume. Repeat this procedure for the other sample. In activity 2, you will remove the plastic bag from the filter and record the mass of the filter and soil. Then, you will allow the soil to dry on newspaper until it feels dry. Next, you will record the mass of the dry soil and calculate the soil moisture. You will then proceed to activity 3.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will decide on your test sites and mark your thermometer. Then, you will draw a map of the soil locations and photograph your test sites. Next, you will insert your thermometer to the given depth, wait 2 minutes, then remove the thermometer and record the temperature. You will do this at all your test sites at soil depths of 1, 2, 4, and 6 centimeters. In Activity 4, you will create a spreadsheet workbook table and enter water drainage data into it. Then you will create a graph from the data. This process is repeated for each data set from Activity 2.

data.title: Capillarity
data.content: The phenomenon whereby water is drawn into narrow spaces in soil

data.title: Field capacity
data.content: The point at which a soil is saturated but all unbound water is drained

data.title: Gravimetric soil moisture (θm)
data.content: The mass of the water in the soil

data.title: Heat of vaporization
data.content: The amount of energy needed to turn a material into a gas

data.title: Hydrostatic potential (Ψh)
data.content: The potential due to overlying layers of water pressing down on the point of interest

data.title: Macropore
data.content: A large pore (greater than 80 micrometers) between individual particles that can be found in soil

data.title: Micropore
data.content: A small pore (less than 80 micrometers) that can be found in soil

data.title: Osmotic potential (Ψ0)
data.content: The potential due to dissolved solutes

data.title: Permanent wilting point
data.content: The point at which water exists in soil but matric potential is too low to make it accessible by a plant

data.title: Saturated soil
data.content: Soil that has all its pores completely filled with water such that a positive matric potential exists

data.title: Soil moisture
data.content: The amount of water in soil

data.title: Specific heat
data.content: The amount of heat energy necessary to raise the temperature of 1 gram of a substance by 1 °C

data.title: Total water potential
data.content: The sum of four types of potential energy - gravitational potential, matric potential, osmotic potential and hydrostatic potential

data.title: Volumetric soil moisture (θv)
data.content: The volume of moisture in soil
